statement.tex: %text Let $A=Q\times Q$, where $Q$ is the set of all rational numbers, and $*$ be a binary operation defined on A by % \begin{align} (a, b)*(c, d)=(ac, b+ad), \forall \left(a, b\right)\left(c, d\right) \in A \end{align} \\ %text Find (i) the identity element in A. (ii) the invertible element of A. %

options.tex: %text If the identity element is the pair $I(i, j) \in A$, then by definition of identity element, % \begin{align} (a, b)*(i, j) &= (a, b) = (i, j)*(a, b) \\ \therefore I(i,j)&=(1,0) \end{align} \\

reason.tex: %text By definition an identity element $I(i, j) \in A$ is such that, % \begin{align} (a, b)*(i, j) = (a, b) = (i, j)*(a, b). \\ \end{align} \\ \\ \begin{align} &(a, b)*(i, j) = (a, b) \\ \implies &(ai, b+aj) = (a, b) \\ \implies &ai = a, b+aj=b \\ \implies &i=1, j=0 \end{align} \\ \begin{align} &(i, j)*(a, b) = (a, b) \\ \implies &(ia, j+ib) = (a, b) \\ \implies &ia = a \text{ and } j+ib=b \\ \implies &i=1, j=0 \end{align}

options.tex: %text If the invertible element is the pair $L (l, m) \in A$, and identity element is $(1,0)$ then, % \begin{align} &(a, b)*(l, m) = (1, 0) = (l, m)*(a, b) \\ \implies &(l,m)=\left(\dfrac{1}{a}, -\dfrac{b}{a}\right) \end{align}
